children.string: Dax Patterns have different levels of complexity
Dax Patterns involve different [[Power BI Functions]]
[[Sometimes its useful to have a table that is NOT in relationships with the other tables in your data model]]
[[Sometimes you want to run different code in your measures depending on the value of some parameter in your model]]
[[You can use a parameter to control the number of records returned by measures like [[RANKX()]]]]
[[The Power BI interface has no mechanism for restricting the]]
If you set the parameter slicer to use a single selection you can re-write to this:
DIVIDE(SUM ( Sales[SalesAmount] ) ,VALUES ( Scale[Scale] ))  on the theory that using DIVIDE is always safer than using the literal "/", since DIVIDE can handle division by 0
If you use a slicer set to do single selection these tests are not necessary. The slicer will always have just one selection.

If you are using a slicer set to single selection and you want to include the possibility that the user might want to make no selection, then include that as one of the options. In this case you might include "0" as the first option for discount percent.
Do not be satisfied with ambiguous or potentially misleading results

The formula is designed to work at the level of the month and above – like quarter and year. Below the month level – like day – the results are inaccurate. At this point, the important question is what the result below the granularity of the formula should be. There are several possible answers; all of them are sort-of correct:
It is fine as it is, no need to fix it; users should not use the measure at the day level.
It always needs to show 1, because each individual date belongs to a month that satisfies the condition.
It must show a blank, because that granularity is not supported.

If you are ok with the first option, then the remaining part of the article is useless. Still, you are quitting the game too early: sooner than later, a user will use and read the values at the unsupported granularity. A real DAX pro does not let their formulas compute an incorrect value. Under. Any. Circumstances [[Russo and Ferrari]]  https://www.sqlbi.com/articles/working-below-a-dax-formulas-granularity/
Whenever I have a model I always hide any column that cannot be aggregated producing some meaningful result.
There are some questions and issues that I have noted, but that I do not understand, or do not understand the full context of

The reason why this formula is wrong is quite subtle: when [VALUES](https://dax.guide/values/) is being evaluated, the context transition still has not taken place. Therefore, the filter on the year/month is not effective yet. This is not an issue at the month or day level inside the matrix, but it provides an incorrect result at the grand total level, where no filter is active. [ALLEXCEPT](https://dax.guide/allexcept/) being a modifier, it executes after the context transition; it efficiently removes any filter except the one on __Date[Calendar Year Month]__ introduced by the context transition.
